column67: It's one of two spots I consider my "home breaks," the one closest to me and the one I surf the most frequently.  When it's on, it's ON.  It can be very challenging and so to a great extent it polices itself.  There are two other breaks very closely associated with it and there is a long running fairly insular crew that have been surfing it regularly for at least as long as I have.  It produces waves year round, although the quantity and quality decline severely during the off season and it can be too big to handle during much of the winter, so it requires a great deal of investment in time and gas to monitor it and make sure it's taken advantage of when conditions are optimal.  To be fully capitalized on requires a great deal of skill and dedication.  Occasionally newcommers possess the skill and tact to integrate quickly but more generally it takes up to several years.  Despite a regular influx of newcomers every year due to the nearby university, there are not often fights or negative attitudes associated with the spot because, as I said, it tends to police itself.  If you don't belong there the spot will generally inform you so it's not usually necessary for a human to intervene.  That said, the locals do command respect and they generally get it.

The spot is accessed via BLM land so it was gated off during the big federal government shut down last year.  Surfers were still al2ed to walk in but it is a substantial hike and in fact a shark attack occurred there during that time so that there were no vehicles on the beach and it took nearly 40 minutes to get an ambulance to the victim. column67: I was born and raised on the beach there, and now am raising my son there. For most long time residents, Silver Strand is both a physical place and a state of mind. It is located in Oxnard, which despite its location on the southern California coast just south of places like Santa Barbara and Ventura, and just north of Malibu (which all possess way more surfers and surf culture than Oxnard), is much more "urban-minded" thanks to its demographics. Silver Strand is on the edge of town, on the edge of the continent, at the end of an "only-one-way-in-only-one-way-out" road. As such, it has long been a magnet for divergent thinkers, weirdos, and a tight-knit tribe of hard core surfers. In the 1980s and 1990s when I was a child, its localism was so notorious that few outsiders ever ventured in. Thanks to Dane, Nick Rosza, and the dozens of other pros who have filmed clips there during our prime wave season and posted them online for all to see, people now know there is perhaps California's best, punchiest beach break. All respect to Black's down in San Diego, but we've got our own submarine canyon funneling peaky tubes in ALL winter, and thanks to the nasty localism rep, it's often still just "the boys" out there on the best days. I surfed Black's plenty, but it's a joke how crowded it is and how unskilled the surfers in the lineup are out there. That shit doesn't fly on the peak at Strand, on good days or shitty days. But times have changed in terms of managing the visitors who come to score, most notably over the last 3 years. I've seen things these last three years that simply COULD NOT have happened when I was younger due to violence and property damage. Things like strangers parking fancy cars full of friends and boards without fear, then paddling out en masse with go Pros to go show their girlfriends or mamas at home how swell they did out at "the Strand" that day. Things like Timmy Patterson boards, manufactured in San Clemente. That was a guaranteed ass-whipping when I was younger, usually administered by "the uncles."  I do not miss the violence and subsequent police harassment of surfers from Strand, I do not miss being classified as a "documented gang member" because I have a Silver Strand Locals (SSL) tatoo, I do not miss the aggression shown towards any vehicle entering the beach (remember: one way in and out, small town, everybody knows everybody else, and if they don't know you, they stare daggers) that is not endemic to the beach. But I do miss surfing on Saturday mornings with just my neighbors and friends, riding boards made by other neighbors and friends, spending time in the water at the place each of us has literally built our lives around, without the frenzy of 500 other guys pulling up from some point inland and paddling out like they own it. I liken it to me (a 33 year-old white guy with average skills) just pulling up at some basketball court in Watts on a Saturday morning, and expecting to get in the game. That ain't happening! Anyway, sorry to ramble, but that's why I love Silver Strand. We all do!

column67: Pleasure Point is amazing. It can be good even when it's a bit windy, it holds up in off shore winds, it is good when the tide is usually less than +4' (outgoing, but best at incoming), it picks up swell best with SSW, SW, W and NW, it is good for longboarding in multiple conditions- little waves on the inside, set waves outside.  /  / I like it best at waist to head 6. It is 2 blocks from my house and I see this spot every day. It is part of the "Point" culture: we walk the beach at 2 tide, we watch the swell during storms, we grab coffee and watch the surf on our Saturday morning... it is a huge part of our culture. When the sea wall went up in front of O'Neill's, there was a lot of controversy that the wall would negatively impact the waves and movement of sand.  /  / Even as a goofy footer, this wave/break/oasis/place of rejuvenation is awesome :)
